sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Women pleas'd. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1647. Date first performed: 1619-1623.

encodingDesc.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Silvio Bartello Soto Claudio Lopez Penurio Isabella Rodope Belvidere Duchesse Syenna Jaquenet 1 Soldier 2 Soldlier Clerk Counsellour 1 Lord 2 Lord Lord Maid 1.Gentleman 2 Gentleman 3 Gentleman
1 Gentlewowan 2 Gentlewoman Captain Farmer Hob. 1 Boy 1 Presenter 2 Presenter Gentleman

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is true she is a right good Princes, and a just one,
And Florence when she sets has lost a Planet.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My Mistress? I tell thee gentle Nephew,
There is not such another friend to goodness,
To down-right dealing, to faith and true heart
Within the Christian confines: Before she blessed us,
Justice was a Cheese-monger, a mere Cheese-monger,
Weighed nothing to the World but mites and maggots,
And a maine stink: Law like a Horse-courser,
Her rules, and precepts hung with gauds and ribbons,
And pampered up to cousin him that bought her,
When she herself was hackney lame and foundered.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But the sweet Lady,
Belvidere the bright one --

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Aye , there is a face indeed: O my dear Nephew,
Could a young fellow of thy fiery mettle
Freeze, and that Lady in his arms?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I think not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou hast a parlous judgment; but let that pass,
She is as truly virtuous, fair, and noble,
As her great Mother is good; and that is not ordinary.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But why (so many Princes, and so great ones
Being Suitors) should the Duchess deny to match her?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: She is a Jewel man, hangs in her bosom,
Her only Child: with her eyes she sees all things,
Discourses with her tongue, and pluck her from her
(So dotingly the old one loves her young one)
You pluck her heart out too: Besides, of late days,
The Duke of Millaine, who could never win her
By love, nor treaty, laid a close train for her
In her own private walks: some forty Horse-men,
So to surprise her; which we found, and dealt with,
And sent them running home to the Duke their Master,
Like Dogs with bottles at their tails.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Since that, I heard Sir,
She has sent her to your Citadel to secure her,
My cousin Rodope, your wife attending her.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You hear a truth, and all convenient pleasures
Are there proportioned for her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I would fain Sir,
Like one that owes a duteous service to her
Sometimes, so please you---

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Gentle Cousin pardon me,
I must not, nor you must not dare to offer,
The last Edict lies on his life pursues it;
Your friend Sir to command, abroad to love you,
To lend ye anything I have, to wait upon ye,
But in the Citadel where I stand charged,
Not a bit upon a march: no service Sir,
No, good Sir by no means: I kiss your hands Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: To your keeping only? none else to look upon her?
None but Bartello worthy her attendance?
No faith but his to serve her? O Belvidere,
Thou Saint to whom my youth is sacrificed,
Thou point to which my life turns, and my fortune,
Art thou locked from me now? from all my comforts,
Art thou snatched violently? thou hearest me not,
Nor canst thou see (fair soul) thy Servants mournings,
Yet let thy gentle heart feele what his absence,
The great divorce of minds so truly loving,
So long, and nursed in one affection
Even from our infant eyes, sucked in and nourished:
O let it feele but that, and there stand constant
And I am blessed. My dear Niece Rodope,
That is her Governess, did love me dearly,
There is one hope yet to see her:when he is absent
It may be ventured, and she may work it closely:
I know the Ladies will goes equal with me,
And so the danger of the Edict avoided;
Let me think more, for I must try all hazards.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Will ye go yonder Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes marry will I Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And by this Ladder?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By that Ladder, coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Have ye any more necks at home when this is broken,
For this will crack with the best friend he has Sir?
Or can you pitch of all four, like an Ape now?
Let me see you tumble.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are very pleasant Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: No truly Sir, I should be loath to see ye
Come fluttering down like a young Rook, cry squab,
And take ye up with your brains beaten into your buttocks

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hold your peace Ass: who is this stands musing here? Silvio?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: One most glad to see you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My dearest Claudio? what make you thus private,
And with a preparation of this nature?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: We have leave to play, and are going to climb Birds nests.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Prithee what is it friend? why start ye from me?
Is your old Mistress grown so coy and cruel,
She must be scaled? it seems you are loath to tell me,
Since twenty years continuance of our friendship
May not be worth the weight of such a secret,
It will be but rude to ask again: save ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay stay,dear Silvio, if you love me take it:
For till you know it, never woman laboured
As I do now.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will do my best to ease it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You have heard the Lady Belvidere --

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What heard Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Heard to the Citadel, upon some fears
She is confined.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why dreams he on this beauty?
It is true, I have heard it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And that no access,
No blessing from those eyes but with much hazard,
Even hazard of a life.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He dares not love her;
I have heard that too: but whither points your purpose?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O Silvio, let me speak that none may hear me,
None but thy truth: I have loved this Lady long,
Long given away my life to her devotion,
Long dwelt upon that beauty to my ruin.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Does she know this?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No, there begins my misery,
Ixion-like, I have only yet clasped Clouds,
And fed upon poor empty dreams that starve me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And what do you mean to do now?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Though I die for it,
Though all the tortures in the world hung on me,
Armed with imperious Love, I stand prepared now,
With this to reach her Chamber: there to see her,
And tell her boldly with what truth I love her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It will not be easily done Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O my Silvio,
The hardest things are sweetest in possession.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nor will show much discretion.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Love is blind man,
And he that looks for reason there far blinder.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Have ye considered ripely?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: All that may fall,
And armed against that all.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Her honour too?
What she may suffer in this rash adventure?
The beauty of her name?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will do it closely,
And only at her window, with that caution --

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Are there no Guards?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Corruption chokes their service.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Or do you hold her bred so light a woman
To hold commerce with strange tongues?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why this service,
This only hazard of my life must tell her,
Though she were Vestas self, I must deserve her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I would not have ye go: pray let it sink here,
And think a nobler way to raise your service,
A safer, and a wiser.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is too late Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then I must say, You shall not go.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I shall not?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You shall not go: that part bred with ye, friendship
Bids me say boldly so, and you observe me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You stretch that tie too far.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will stretch it farther:
The honour that I bear that spotless virtue
You foully seek to taint, unnobly covet,
Bids me command ye stay: if not, thus force ye.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: This will be worse than climbing.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why do ye draw Sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: To kill thee, if thy base will be thy Master.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I ever was your friend.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Whilst thou wert honest,
And not a Night-thief of another's honour;
I never called a Fool my friend, a mad-man,
That durst expose his fame to all opinions,
His life to unhonest dangers: I never loved him,
Durst know his name, that sought a Virgins ruin,
Nor ever took I pleasure in acquaintance
With men, that give as loose reins to their fancies
As the wild Ocean to his raging fluxes:
A noble soul I twin with, and my love
Follows, his life dares master his affections.
Will ye give off, or fight?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will not fight with ye:
The sacred name of friend ties up that anger,
Rather I will study.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Do, to be a friend still.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If this way, I shall never hold.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will watch ye:
And if I catch ye false: by Heaven ye die for it,
All love forgot.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: When I fear that I am fit for it.

body.stage: Enter Lopez at a Table with jewels and money upon it, an Egg roasting by a Candle.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Whilst prodigal young gaudy Fools are banqueting,
And launching out their states to catch the giddy,
Thus do I study to preserve my fortune,
And hatch with care at home the wealth that Saints me.
Here is Rubies of Bengala, rich, rich, glorious;
These Diamonds of Ormus bought for little,
Here vented at the price of Princes Ransoms;
How bright they shine like constellations,
The South seas treasure here, Pearl, fair and orient
Able to equal Cleapatra's Banquet,
Here chains of lesser stones for Ladies lustres,
Ingots of Gold, Rings, Brooches, bars of Silver,
These are my studies to set off in sale well,
And not in sensual surfeits to consume them;
How roasts mine egg? he heats apace, I will turn him:
Penurio, where you knave do you wait? Penurio,
You lazy knave.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Did you call Sir?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Where is your Mistress?
What vanity holds her from her attendance?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The very sight of this egg has made him cockish,
What would a dozen buttered do? She is within Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Within Sir, at what thrift ye knave? what getting?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Getting a good stomach Sir, and she knew where to get meat to it,
She is praying heartily upon her knees Sir,
That Heaven would send her a good bearing dinner.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nothing but gluttony and surfeit thought on,
Health flung behind: had she not yesternight sirra
Two Sprats to supper, and the oil allowable?
Was she not sick with eating? Hadst not thou,
(Thou most ungrateful knave, that nothing satisfies)
The water that I boiled my other egg in
To make thee hearty broth?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It is true, I had Sir;
But I might as soon make the Philosophers Stone on it,
You gave it me in water, and but for manners sake,
I could give it you again in wind, it was so hearty
I shall turn pissing Conduit shortly: my Mistress comes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Welcome my Dove.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Pray ye keep your welcome to ye,
Unless it carries more than words to please me,
Is this the joy to be a Wife? to bring with me,
Besides the nobleness of blood I spring from,
A full and able portion to maintain me?
Is this the happiness of youth and beauty,
The great content of being made a Mistress,
To live a Slave subject to wants, and hungers,
To jealousies for every eye that wanders?
Unmanly jealousy.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Good Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Too good for you: do you think to famish me,
Or keep me like an Alms-woman in such raiment,
Such poor unhandsome weeds? am I old, or ugly?
I never was bred thus: and if your misery
Will suffer wilful blindness to abuse me,
My patience shall be no Bawd to mine own ruin.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Tickle him Mistress: to him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Had ye love in ye,
Or any pat of man --

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Follow that Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Or had humanity but ever known ye,
You would shame to use a woman of my way thus,
So poor, and basely: you are strangely jealous of me
If I should give ye cause.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: How Isabella?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: As do not venture this way to provoke me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Excellent well Mistress,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: How is this Isabella?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: It will stir a Saint, and I am but a woman,
And by that tenure may.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: By no means Chicken,
You know I love ye: fie, take no example
By those young gadding Dames: (you are noted virtuous)
That stick their Husbands wealth in trifles on them
And point them but the way to their own miseries:
I am not jealous, kiss me, -- I am not:
And for your diet, it is to keep you healthful,
Surfeits destroy more than the sword: that I am careful
Your meat should be both neat, and cleanly handled
See, Sweet, I am Cook myself, and mine own Cater.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A -- of that Cook cannot lick his fingers.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I will add another dish: you shall have Milk to it,
It is nourishing and good.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: With Butter in it Sir?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This knave would breed a famine in a Kingdom:
And cloths that shall content ye: you must be wise then,
And live sequestered to yourself and me,
Not wandering after every toy comes cross ye,
Nor struck with every spleen: what is the knave doing? Penurio.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Hunting Sir, for a second course of flies here,
They are rare new Salads.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: For certain Isabella
This ravening fellow has a Woolf in his belly:
Untemperate knave, will nothing quench thy appetite?
I saw him eat two Apples, which is monstrous.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: If you had given me those it had been more monstrous.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It is a maine miracle to feed this villain,
Come Isabella, let us in to Supper,
And think the Romane dainties at our Table,
It is all but thought.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Would all my thoughts would do it:
The Devil should think of purchasing that Eggshell,
To victual out a Witch for the Burmoothes:
It is treason to any good stomach living now
To hear a tedious Grace said, and no meat to it,
I have a Radish yet, but that is but transitory.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Can any living man unless a Rascal
That neither knows himself, nor a fashioned Gentleman
Take me for a worse man than my Master now?
I am naturally proud in these cloths: but if pride now
Should catch a fall in what I am attempting,
It is but a Proverb sound, and a Neck broken,
That is the worst can come on it : a Gentleman is gone then,
A Gentleman of the first house, there is the end on it:
My Master lies most pitifully complaining,
Wringing and kicking up to the ears in love yonder,
And such a lamentable noise he keeps, it kills me:
I have got his cloths, and if I can get to her
By hook or crook here, such a song I will sing her --~
I think I shall be hanged, but that is no matter,
What is a hanging among friends: I am valiant now as an Elephant;
I have considered what to say too: let me see now,
This is the place, it is plaguey high: stay at that lower window
Let me aim finely now, like a good Gunner,
It may prove but a whipping.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I saw somebody
Pass by me now, and though it were dark, methought yet
I knew the clothes: have, let me not be cozened,
The Ladder too, ready to fling it? monstrous,
It is he, it is Claudio: most voluptuous villain,
Scandal to woman's credit: Love, I forget thee.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: What will he do in the name of heaven, what is that there?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And all the friendship that I bore thee, bury here.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: What has he in his hand? I hope but a Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thy fault's forgive O Heaven: farewell thou traitor.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I am slain: I am slain.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He is down, and dead: dead certain,
It was too rash, too full of spleen, stark dead:
This is no place now to repent in, only
Would I had given this hand that shot the Pistol
I had missed thee, and thou wert once more Claudio.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why should I love thus foolishly? thus desperately?
And give away my heart where no hope is left me?
Why should not the true counsel of a friend restrain me?
The Devils mouth I run into affright me,
The honour of the Lady charm my wildness;
I have no power, no being of myself,
No reason strong enough now left within me
To bind my will: O Love, thou God, or Devil,
Or what thou art that plays the tyrant in me.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: O .

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What is that cry?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A Surgeon, a Surgeon,
Twenty good Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is not far from me,
Some Murther on my life,

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Will you let me die here?
No drink come, nor no Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is my man sure,
His voice, and here he lies: how is it with thee?

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.l: I am slain, Sir, I am slain.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Slain? Who has slain thee?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Killed, killed, out-right killed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Where is thy hurt?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I know not,
But I am sure I am killed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Canst thou sit up,
That I may find the hurt out?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I can sit up,
But nevertheless I am slain.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is not on this side?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: No Sir, I think it be not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nor on this side,
Was it done with a Sword?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A Gun, a Gun sweet Master.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The devil a bullet has been here: thou art well, man.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: No sure, I am killed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Let me see thy thighs, and belly,
As whole as a fish for anything I see yet:
Thou bleedest nowhere.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I think I do not bleed Sir,
But yet I am afraid I am slain.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Stand up Fool,
Thou hast as much hurt as my nail: who shot thee,
A Pottle, or a Pint?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Seignior Silvio shot me
In these clothes, taking me for you, and seeing
The Ladder in my hand here, which I stole from ye,
Thinking to have gone to the Lady self, and have spoke for ye

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If he had hit ye home, he had served ye right sirrah,
You saucy rogue, how poor my intent shows to me,
How naked now, and foolish?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Are ye sure he has not hit me,
It gave a monstrous bounce?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You risse of your right side,
And said your prayers too, you had been payed else:
But what needest thou a Bullet when thy fear kills thee?
Sirrah, keep your own counsel for all this, you will be hanged else,
If it be known.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: If it be by my means let me;
I am glad I am not killed, and far more gladder
My gentleman-like humours out: I feele it is dangerous,
And to be a gentleman, is to be killed twice a week.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Keep yourself close in the Country for a while sirrah.
There is Money, walk to your friends.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: They have no Pistols,
Nor are no Gentlemen, that is my comfort.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will retire too, and live private; for this Silvio
Inflamed with nobleness will be my death else;
And if I can forget this love that loads me,
At least the danger: and now I think on it better,
I have some conclusions else invites me to it.

body.stage: Enter Rodope, and Silvio at several doors.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nephew.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My dear Aunt.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Would you go by thus slyly
And never see me, not once send in to me
Your loving Niece? she that above all those
I call my Kindred honoured you, and placed you
Nearest my heart?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I thank you worthy Cousin,
But such at this time are my occasions --

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You shall not go yet, by my faith you shall not,
I will not be denied: why look ye sad Nephew?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am seldom other: O, this blood sits heavy:
As I walked this way late last night,
In meditation of some things concerned me --

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What Nephew?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why me thought I heard a Piece, Lady,
A piece shot off, much about this place too,
But could not judge the cause, nor what it boded,
Under the Castle wall.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We heard it too,
And the Watch pursued it presently, but found nothing,
Not any tract.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am right glad to hear it:
The Ruffians surely, that command the night
Have found him, stripped him: and into the River
Conveyed the body.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You look still sadder, Nephew,
Is anything within these walls to comfort ye?
Speak, and be Master of it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ye are a right Courtier,
A great Professor, but a poor performer.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do you doubt my faith: you never found me that way
I dare well speak it boldly, but a true friend.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Continue then.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Try me, and see who falters.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will, and presently: it is in your power
To make me the most bound man to your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Let me know how, and if I fail --

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is thus then,
Get me access to the Lady Belvidere
But for a minute, but to see her: your Husband now
Is safe at Court, I left him full employed there.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You have asked the thing without my power to grant ye,
The Law lies on the danger: if I loved ye not
I would bid ye go, and there be found, and die for it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I knew your love, and where there showed a danger
How far you durst step for me: give me a true friend,
That where occasion is to do a benefit
Aims at the end, and not the rubs before it;
I was a fool to ask ye this, a more fool
To think a woman had so much noble nature
To entertain a secret of this burthen;
Ye had best to tell the Duchess I persuaded ye,
That is a fine course, and one will win ye credit;
Forget the name of Cousin, blot my blood out,
And so you raise yourself, let me grow shorter.
A woman friend? he that believes that weakness
Steers in a stormy night without a Compass.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What is it I durst not do might not impeach ye?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why this ye dare not do, ye dare not think of.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: It is a maine hazard.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If it were not so
I would not come to you to seek a favour.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You will lose yourself.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The loss ends with self then.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You will but see her?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Only look upon her.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not stay?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Prescribe your time.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not traffic with her
In any close dishonourable actions?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Stand you your self by.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I will venture for ye,
Because ye shall be sure I am a touched friend,
I will bring her to ye: come walk, you know the Garden,
And take this key to open the little Postern,
There stand no guards.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I shall soon find it Cousin.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: Is the Captain come home?

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: No, who commands the Guard tonight?

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: I think Petruchio.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: What is the Word?

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: None knows yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: I would this Lady were married out of the way once,
Or out of our custodies; I wish they would take in more companies,
For I am sure we feel her in our duties shrewdly.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: It is not her fault I warrant ye, she is ready for it ,
And that is the plague, when they grow ripe for marriage
They must be slipped like Hawks.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: Give me a mean wench,
No State doubt lies on her, she is always ready.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: Come to the Guard, it is late, and sure the Captain
Cannot be long away.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: I have watched these three nights,
Tomorrow they may keep me tame for nothing.

body.stage: Enter Silvio, Belvidere, and Rodope with a light.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This is the place I think; what Light is that there?
The Lady and my Cousin?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is this the Garden?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O my blessed Mistress,
Saint of my soul.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Speak softly: take me to ye,
O Silvio I am thine, thine ever Silvio.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Is this your promise Sir? Lady your honour?
I am undone if this be seen, disgraced,
Fallen under all discredit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do you love still?
Dear, do you keep your old faith?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ever Lady;
And when that fails me, all that is good forsake me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do not you shame? Madam, I must not suffer this,
I will not suffer it; men call you virtuous,
What do you mean to lose yourself thus? Silvio
I charge thee get away, charge you retire ye,
I will call the watch else.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Call all the world to see us,
We live in one another's happiness,
And so will die.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Here will I hang for ever.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: As ye respect me, as hereafter Madam
You would enjoy his love -- nothing prevail with ye?
I will try my strength then; get thee gone thou villain,
Thou Promise-breaker.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am tide, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I will ring the Bell then.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ring it to death, I am fixed here.

body.stage: Enter Bartello, two Soldiers with lights.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: I saw a light over the Garden walk,
Hard by the Ladies Chamber, here is some knavery
As I live, I saw it twice.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The Guard, the Guard there;
I must not suffer this, it is too mischievous.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Light up the torch, I feared this, ha? young Silvio?
How got he in?

sp.speaker: 1.Sold.
sp.l: The Devil brought him in sure
He came not by us.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: My wife between them bustling?
Guard, pull him off.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Now, now, ye feele the misery.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: You, Madam, at an hour so far undecent?
Death, O my soul! this is a foul fault in ye,
Your mothers care abused too, light us to her Chamber,
I am sorry to see this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Farewell my Sylvio.
And let no danger sink thee.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nor death Lady.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Are ye so hot? I shall prepare ye Physic
Will purge ye finely, neatly; you are too fiery,
Think of your prayers, Sir, and you have not forgot them;
Can ye fly in the air, or creep ye in at key-holes?
I have a gin will catch ye though you conjured:
Take him to Guard tonight, to strong and sure Guard;
I will back to the Duchess presently: no less sport serve ye,
Than the Heir to a Dukedom? play at push-pin there Sir?
It was well aimed, but plague upon it, you shot short,
And that will lose your game.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I know the loss then.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Now, in this habit may I safely see
How my incensed friend carries my murther,
Who little I imagined had been wrought
To such a height of rage; and much I grieve now
Mine own blind passion had so mastered me,
I could not see his love, for sure he loves her,
And on a nobler ground than I pretended.
It must be so, it is so; what Penurio,
My shotten friend, what wind blew you?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Faith it is true,
Any strong wind will blow me like a feather,
I am all Air, nothing of earth within me,
Nor have not had this month, but that good Dinner
Your Worship gave me yesterday, that stays by me,
And gives me ballast, else the Sun would draw me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But does my Mistress speak still of me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
And in her sleep, that makes my Master mad too,
And turn and fart for anger.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Are sure she saw me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: She saw ye at a window.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is most true,
In such a place I saw a Gentlewoman,
A young, sweet handsome woman.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That is she, that is she Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And well she viewed me, I viewed her.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Still she Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: At last she blushed, and then looked off.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That blush Sir,
If you can read it truly --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But didst thou tell her,
Or didst thou fool me, thou knewest such a one?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I told her, and I told her such a sweet tale --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But did she hear thee?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: With a thousand ears Sir,
And swallowed what I said as greedily,
As great-bellied women do Cherries, stones and all Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Methinks she should not love thy Master?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Hang him Pilcher,
There is nothing loves him: his own Cat cannot endure him,
She had better lie with a Bear, for he is so hairy,
That a tame warren of flies frisk round about him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And wilt thou work still?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Like a Miner for ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And get access.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Or conjure you together,
It is her desire to meet: she is poisoned with him,
And till she take a sweet fresh air, that is you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There is money for thee: thou art a precious Varlet,
Be fat, be fat, and blow thy Master backward.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Blow you my Mistress Sir, as flat as a flounder,
Then blow her up again as Butchers blow their Veals;
If she die upon the same
Bury her, bury her in Gods name.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thou art a merry knave: by this hand I will feed thee,
Till thou crackest at both ends, if thou darest do this
Thou shalt eat no fantastical Porridge,
Nor lick the dish where oil was yesterday,
Dust, and dead flies today; Capons, fat Capons---

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O hearty sound.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Crammed full of itching Oysters.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Will ye have the Duchess?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And Lobsters big as Gauntlets,
Thou shalt despise base Beef.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I do despise it,
And now me thinks I feele a Tart come sliding.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Leaping into thy mouth: but first deal faithfully.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: When will ye come?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I will attend ye,
For then my Master will be out in business.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What news abroad?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Mass as I was coming to you,
I heard that Seignior Silvio, a good Gentleman,
Many a good meal I have eaten with him --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Was this day to be Arraigned before the Duchess,
But why I could not hear.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Silvio arraigned?
Go, get ye gone, and think of me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I fly Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Arraigned? for what? for my supposed death? no,
That cannot be sure, there is no rumour of it,
Be it what it will, I will be there and see it,
And if my help will bring him off he has it.

body.stage: Enter Duchess, Lords, Silvio prisoner, Belvidere, Bartello, Rodope, Clerke, Counsellors, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Read the Edict last made,
Keep silence there.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: If any man of what condition soever, and a subject, after the publishing of this Edict, shall without special Licence from the great Duchess, attempt or buy, offer, or make an attempt, to solicit the love of the Princess Belvidere the person so offending shall forfeit his life.

sp.speaker: Counsellour.
sp.l: The reason why my Royal Mistress here
In her last Treaty with Siennas Duke,
Promised her beauteous Daughter there in marriage,
The Duke of Millaine, rival in this fortune,
Un-nobly sought by practise to betray her;
Which found, and crossed, the Citadel received her
There to secure her Mothers word; the last cause
So many Gentlemen of late enamoured
On this most beauteous Princess, and not brooking
One more than other, to deserve a favour,
Blood has been spilt, many brave spirits lost,
And more unless she had been kept close from their violence
Had like to have followed: therefore for due prevention
Of all such hazards and innoble actions,
This last Edict was published, which thou Silvio
Like a false man, a bad man, and a Traitor
Hast rent a-pieces, and contemned; for which cause
Thou standest a guilty man here now.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.l: Speak Silvio,
What canst thou say to avoid the hand of Justice?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nothing, but I confess, submit,and lay my head to it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have ye no eyes my Lords, no understandings?
The Gentleman will cast himself away,
Cast himself wilfully: are you, or you guilty?
No more is he, no more taint sticks upon him:
I drew him thither, it was my way betrayed him,
I got the entrance kept, I entertained him,
I hid the danger from him, forced him to me,
Poor gentle soul, he is in no part transgressing,
I wrote unto him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Do not wrong that honour,
Cast not upon that pureness these aspersions,
By Heaven it was my love, my violence,
My life must answer it: I broke into; her,
Tempted the Law, solicited unjustly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As there is truth in Heaven I was the first cause,
How could this man have come to me, left naked
Without my counsel and provision?
What hour could he find out to pass the Watches,
But I must make it sure first? Reverend Judges,
Be not abused, nor let an innocent life lie
Upon your shaking Conscience; I did it,
My love the maine wheel that set him a going:
His motion but compelled.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Can ye believe this,
And know with what a modesty and whiteness
Her life was ever ranked? Can you believe this
And see me here before ye young, and wilful?
Apt to what danger Love dares thrust me on,
And where Law stops my way, apt to contemn it?
If I were bashful, old, or dull, and sleepy
In Loves alarms, a woman might awake me,
Direct, and clew me out the way to happiness:
But I like fire, kindled with that bright beauty,
Catch hold of all occasions, and run through them.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I charge ye as your honest souls will answer it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I charge ye, as you are the friends to virtue,
That has no pattern living but this Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let not his blood --

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Let not her wilfulness --
For then you act a scene Hell will rejoice at.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He is clear.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: She is as white in this as infants.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The god of Love protect your cause, and help ye,
Two nobler pieces of affection
These eyes never looked on, if such goodness perish,
Let never true hearts meet again, but break.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: A strange example of strong love, a rare one.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: Madam, we know not what to say to think on.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I must confess it strikes me tender too,
Searches my Mothers heart: you found them there?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes certain Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: And so linked together?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As they had been one piece of Alabaster.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Nothing dishonourable?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: So let my soul have happiness,
As that thought yet durst never seek this bosom.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: What shall I do? he has broke my Law, abused me,
Fain would I know the truth, either confess it,
And let me understand the maine offender,
Or both shall feele the torture.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Are ye a Mother?
The Mother of so sweet a Rose as this is?
So pure a Flower? and dare ye lose that nature?
Dare ye take to yourself so great a wickedness,
(O holy Heaven) of thinking what may ruin
This goodly building? this temple where the gods dwell?
Give me a thousand tortures, I deserve them,
And show me death in all the shapes imagined.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No death but I will answer it, meet it, seek it;
No torture but I will laugh upon it, and kiss it.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: This is no way.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: They say no more for certain
Than their strong hearts will suffer.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I have bethought me;
No Lords, although I have a Child offending,
Nature dares not forget she is a Child still;
Till now I never looked on love imperious:
I have bethought me of a way to break ye,
To separate, though not your loves your bodies:
Silvio attend, I will be your Judge myself now,
The sentence of your death (because my Daughter
Will bear an equal part in your afflictions)
I take away and pardon: this remains then
An easy, and a gentle punishment,
And this shall be fulfilled: because unnobly
You have sought the love, and marriage of a Princess,
The absolute and sole Heir of this Dukedom,
By that means as we must imagine strongly,
To plant yourself into this Rule hereafter,
We here pronounce ye a man banished from us.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Forever banished Lady?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Yet more mercy,
But for a year: and then again in this place
To make your full appearance: yet more pity,
If in that time you can absolve a question,
Writ down within this scroll, absolve it rightly,
This Lady is your wife, and shall live with ye;
If not, you loose your head.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I take this honour,
And humbly kiss those Royal hands.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Receive it: Bartello, to your old guard take the Princess,
And so the Court break up.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Farewell to all,
And to that spotless heart my endless service.

sp.speaker: 1.Lord.
sp.l: What will this prove?

sp.speaker: 2.Lord.
sp.l: I will tell you a year hence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Are you pleased now? have I not wrought this wonder
Non eben fatto Seignior.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Rarely Penurio.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Close, close then, and work wax.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am studying for thee
A dinner, that shall victual thee for ten year.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Do you hear Mistress?
You know what a dundier whelp my Master is,
I need not preach to ye, how unfit and wanting
To give a woman satisfaction:
How he stinks, and snores, a Bull is a better bed-fellow;
And for his love never let that deceive ye.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Nay sure he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: If he could coin ye,
Or turn ye into mettle much might be then;
He loves not anything but what is traffic:
I have heard him swear he would sell ye to the grand Seignior.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: The Turk.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The very Turk, and how they would use ye.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I will fit him for it: the Turk?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I know the price too:
Now ye have time to pay him, pay him home Mistress;
Pay him of the pate, clout him for all his courtesies;
Here is one that dances in your eyes, young delicate
To work this vengeance; if ye let it slip now,
There is no pitying of ye, gods precious, Mistress,
Were I his wife, I would so mall his Mazard,
It is charity, mere charity, pure charity,
Are you the first? has it not been from Eves time,
Women would have their safe revenges this way?
And good, and gracious women, excellent women;
Is it not a handsome Gentleman? a sweet Gentleman?
View him from head to foot, a complete Gentleman;
When can ye hope the like again? I leave ye,
And my revenge too, with ye; I know my Office,
I will not be far off, be not long a fumbling,
When danger shall appear, I will give the alarm.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You are welcome Sir, and would it were my fortune
To afford a Gentleman of your fair seeming,
A freer entertainment than this house has,
You partly know Sir. --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Know, and pity Lady,
Such sweetness in the bud, should be so blasted;
Dare you make me your Servant?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Dare you make Sir,
That service worthy of a woman's favour
By constancy and goodness?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Here I swear to ye,
By the unvalued love I bear this beauty,
(And kiss the Book too) never to be recreant,
To honour ye, to truly love, and serve ye,
My youth to wait upon ye, what my wealth has.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O make me not so poor, to sell affection,
Those bought love's Sir, were faster than the moneys;
A handsome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A most delicate sweet one,
Let my truth Purchase then.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I should first try it,
But you may happily. --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You shall not doubt me,
I hope she loves me; when I prove false shame take me;
Will ye believe a little?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I fear, too much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And will ye love a little?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: That should be your part.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thus I begin then, thus and thus.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: A good beginning,
We have a Proverb says, makes a good ending.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Say ye so? it is well inferred.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Good Sir, your patience:
Methinks I have ventured now, like a weak Bark
Upon a broken billow, that will swallow me,
Upon a rough sea of suspicions,
Stuck round with jealous rocks.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Ahem, ahem there.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: This is my man; my fears too soon have found me,
Now what is the news?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A pox of yonder old Rigell,
The Captain, the old Captain.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: What old Captain?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Captain courageous yonder of the Castle,
Captain dondeigo, old Bartello.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He is coming in:
It would vex the Devil, that such an old Potgun as this,
That can make no sport, should hinder them that can do it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I would not have him see the Gentleman
For all the world, my credit were undone then.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Shall I fling a piss-pot on his head as he comes in,
And take him into the Kitchen, there to dry him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: That will not do; and he is so humorous too
He will come in.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: One much troubles me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And can do nothing, cannot eat.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Your sight now,
Out of a drivelling dotage he bears to me,
May make him tell my husband, and undo me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What would ye have me do?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: But for a while Sir,
Step here behind this hanging, presently
I will answer him, and then. --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will obey ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Where is my rich Jeweller? I have stones to set.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He is abroad, and sure Sir.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: There is for your service:
Where is the fair Lady? all alone sweet beauty?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: She is never much alone Sir, that is acquainted
With such companions as good honest thoughts are.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I will sit down by thee, and I will kiss thy hand too,
And in thine ear swear by my life I love thee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ye are a merry Captain.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And a mad one, Lady;
By the mas thou hast goodly eyes, excellent eyes, wench,
Ye twinkling rogue, look what thy Captain brings thee,
Thou must needs love me, love me heartily,
Hug me, and love me, hug me close.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Fie Captain.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay, I have strength, and I can strain ye sirra,
And vault into my seat as nimbly, little one.
As any of your smooth chinned boys in Florence,
I must needs commit a little folly with ye,
I will not be long, a bridling case, and away wench;
The hobnail thy husband is as fitly out of the way now.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Do you think he keeps a bawdy house?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That is all one.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Or did you ever see that lightness in my carriage,
That you might promise to yourself --

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Away fool,
A good turn is a good turn; I am an honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You have a handsome wife, a virtuous Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are not for this time of the year.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: A Lady,
That ever bore that great respect to you,
That noble constancy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That is more than I know.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O Mistress, ye are undone, my Master is coming.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Coming hard by here.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Plague Consume the Rascal,
Shall I make petty-patties of him?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Now what love Sir?
Fear of your coming made him jealous first;
Your finding here, will make him mad and desperate,
And what in that wild mood he will execute --

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I can think of nothing, I have no wit left me,
Certain my heads a mustard-pot.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I have thought Sir.
And if you will please to put in execution
What I conceive --

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I will do it, tell it quickly.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Draw your Sword quickly, and go down enraged,
As if you had pursued some foe up hither,
And grumble to yourself extremely, terribly,
But not a word to him, and so pass by him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I will do it perfectly.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Stand you still good Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Rascal, slave, villain, take a house so poorly,
After thou hast wronged a Gentleman, a Soldier,
Base Poltroon boy, you will forsake your nest sirra.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The matter, good sweet Captain?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Run-away rogue,
And take a house to cover thy base cowardice,
I will whip ye, I will so scourge ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Mercy upon me,
What is all this matter wife?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Did you meet the mad man?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I never saw the Captain so provoked yet.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O he is a Devil sure, a most bloody devil,
He followed a young Gentleman, his sword drawn,
With such a fury, how I shake to think on it,
And foined, and flashed at him, and swore he would kill him,
Drove him up hither, followed him still bloodily,
And if I had not hid him, sure had slain him;
A merciless old man.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Most virtuous Lady,
Even as the giver of my life, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This fellow must not stay here, he is too hansom;
He is gone Sir, and you may pass now with all security,
I will be your guide myself, and such a way
I will lead ye, none shall cross, nor none shall know ye.
The door is left open Sirrah, I will starve you for this trick,
I will make thee fast on Sundays; and for you Lady,
I will have your lodgings, farther off, and closer,
I will have no street lights to you; will you go Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir; the Devil take this fortune;
And once more all my service to your goodness.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now could I eat my very arms for madness,
Crossed in the nick of the matter? vengeance take it,
And that old Cavalier that spoiled our Cock-fight;
I will lay the next plot surer.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I am glad and sorry;
Glad, that I got so fairly off suspicion;
Sorry I lost my new loved friend.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Not lost Mistress;
I will conjure once again to raise that spirit;
In, and look soberly upon the matter,
We will ring him one peal more, and if that fall,
The Devil take the clappers, bells, and all.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Now, Rhodope, How do you find my daughter?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Madam, I find her now what you would have her,
What the State wishes her; I urged her fault to her,
Opened her eyes, and made her see the mischief
She was running with a headlong will into,
Made her start at her folly, shake and tremble,
At the mere memory of such an ignorance,
She now contemns his love, hates his remembrance,
Cannot endure to hear the name of Silvio;
His person spits at.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I am glad to hear this.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And humbly now to your will, your care, Madam,
Bends her affections, bows her best obedience;
Syennas Duke, with new eyes now she looks on,
And with a Princely love, fit for his person,
Returns that happiness and joy he looked for;
The general good of both the neighbour Dukedoms,
Not any private end, or rash affection
She aims at now: hearing the Duke arrived too,
(To whom she owes all honour, and all service,)
She charged me kneel thus at your Graces feet,
And not to rise without a general pardon.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: She has it, and my love again, my old love,
And with more tenderness I meet this penitence,
Than if she never had started from her honour;
I thank ye Rhodope, am bound to thank ye,
And daily to remember this great service,
This honest faithful service; go in peace,
And by this Ring, delivered to Bartello,
Let her enjoy our favour, and her liberty,
And presently to this place, with all honour,
See her conducted.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Your Grace has made me happy.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: Syennas noble Duke, craves his admittance.

body.stage: Enter Duke of Syenna with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Go, wait upon his Grace; fair Sir, you are welcome,
Welcome to her ever admired your vertues:
And now, methinks , my Court looks true nobly;
You have taken too much pains, Sir.

sp.speaker: Syen.
sp.l: Royal Lady,
To wait upon your Grace is but my service.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Keep that Sir, for the Saint ye have vowed it to.

sp.speaker: Syen.
sp.l: I keep a life for her: Since your Grace pleases
To jump so happily into the matter,
I come indeed to claim your royal promise,
The beauteous Belvidere in marriage,
I come to tender her my youth, my fortune,
My everlasting love.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You are like to win Sir:
All is forgot, forgiven too; no sadness
My good Child, you have the same heart still here,
The Duke of Syenna, Child, pray use him nobly.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: An Angel beauty.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your Grace is fairly welcome,
And what in modesty a blushing maid may
Wish to a Gentleman of your great goodness;
But wishes are too poor a pay for Princes.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You have made me richer than all States and Titles,
One kiss of this white hand is above all honours,
My faith dear Lady, and my fruitful service,
My duteous zeal --

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your Grace is a great Master,
And speak too powerfully to be resisted:
Once more you are welcome Sir, to me you are welcome,
To her that honours ye; I could say more Sir,
But in another's tongue it were better spoken,

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: As wife as fair, you have made your Servant happy;
I never saw so rich a Mine of sweetness.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Will your Grace please, after your painful journey
To take some rest? Are the Dukes Lodgings ready?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: All Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Then wait upon his Grace, all, and tomorrow Sir
We will show ye in what high esteem we hold ye,
Till then a fair repose.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: My fairest service

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You have so honoured me, my dearest Daughter,
So truly pleased me in this entertainment,
I mean your loving carriage to Syenna,
That both forever I forget all trespasses,
And to secure you next of my full favour,
Ask what you will within my power to grant ye,
Ask freely: and if I forget my promise --
Ask confidently.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are too royal to me,
To me that have so foolishly transgressed you,
So like a Girl, so far forgot my virtue,
Which now appears as base and ugly to me,
As did his Dream, that thought he was in Paradise,
Awaked and saw the Devil; how was I wandered?
With what eyes could I look upon that poor, that course thing,
That wretched thing called Silvio? that (now) despised thing?
And lose an object of that graceful sweetness;
That god-like presence as Syenna is?
Darkness,and cheerful day had not such difference:
But I must ever bless your care, your wisdom,
That led me from this labyrinth of folly,
How had I sunk else? what example given?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Prithee no more, and as thou art my best one,
Ask something that may equal such a goodness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why did ye let him go so slightly from ye,
More like a man in triumph, than condemned?
Why did ye make his penance but a question,
A riddle, every idle wit unlocks.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: It is not so,
Nor do not fear it so: he will not find it,
I have given that unless (myself discover it)
Will cost his head.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It is subject to construction?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: That it is too.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It may be then absolved,
And then are we both scorned and laughed at, Madam;
Beside the promise you have tied upon it,
Which you must never keep.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I never meant it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For heaven sake let me know it, it is my Suit to ye,
The Boon you would have me ask; let me but see it,
That if there be a way to make it so strong,
No wit nor powerful reason can run through it,
For my disgrace, I may beg of heaven to grant it.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Fear not, it has been put to sharper judgments
Than ere he shall arrive at: my dear Father,
That was as fiery in his understanding,
And ready in his wit as any living,
Had it two years, and studied it, yet lost it:
This night ye are my Bed-fellow, there Daughter
Into your bosom I will commit this secret,
And there we will both take counsel.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I shall find
Some trick I hope too strong yet for his mind.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Methinks I am battened well of late, grown lusty,
Fat, high, and kicking, thanks to the bounteous Rugio;
And now, methinks I scorn these poor repasts,
Cheese parings, and the stinking tongues of Pilchers;
But why should I remember these? they are odious,
They are odious in mine eyes; the full fat dish now,
The bearing dish is that I reverence,
The dish an able Serving-man sweats under,
And bends in the hams, as if the house hung on him,
That dish is the dish: hang your bladder Banquets,
Or half a dozen of Turnip, and two Mushrumps,
These when they breed their best, hatch but two Belches;
The state of a fat Turkey, the decorum
He marches in with, all the train and circumstance;
It is such a matter, such a glorious matter,
And then his sauce, with Oranges and Onions,
And he displayed in all parts, for such a dish now,
And at my need I would betray my father,
And for a roasted Conger, all my Country.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What my friend Lean-gut, how does thy beauteous Mistress?
And where is your Master Sirrah? where is that horn-pipe?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My Mistress Sir, does as a poor wronged Gentlewoman,
Too much heaven knows oppressed with injuries,
May do and live.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is the old fool still jealous?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: As old fools are, and will be still the same Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He must have cause: he must have cause.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It is true Sir,
And would he had with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He shall have.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: For then he had Salt to his Saffron Porridge.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why do not I see thee sometime? why thou starved rascal?
Why do not ye come to me, you precious bow-case?
I keep good meat at home, good store:

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
I will not fail ye all next week.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou art welcome,
I have a secret I would fain impart to thee,
But thou art so thin the wind will blow it from thee,
Or men will read it through thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Wrapped up in beef Sir,
In good gross beef, let all the world look on me,
The English have that trick to keep intelligence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A witty knave, first there is to tie your tongue up,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Dumb as a Dog Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Next, hark in your ear, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Well, very well, excellent well:it is done Sir,
Say no more to me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Say and hold.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It is done Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As thou lovest buttered eggs, swear.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Let me kiss the Book first,
But here is my hand, brave Captain.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Look ye hold, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O the most precious vanity of this world
When such dry Neats-tongues must be soaked and larded
With young fat supple wenches? O the Devil,
What can he do, he cannot suck an egg off
But his back is loose in the hilts; go thy wales Captain,
Well may thy Warlike name work Miracles,
But if ever thy foundered courser win match more,
Or stand right but one train --

sp.speaker: 1.Gent.
sp.l: Now Seignior Shadow,
What art thou thinking of, how to rob thy Master?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Of his good deeds? the Thief that undertakes that
Must have a hook will pose all Hell to hammer:
Have ye dined Gentlemen, or do you purpose?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Dined, two long hours ago.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Pray ye take me with ye.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: To supper dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That has the smell of meat in it: tell me true, Gentlemen,
Are not you three now going to be sinful,
To jeopard a joint, or so? I have found your faces,
And see whore written in your eyes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: A parlous Rascal,
Thou art much upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Have a care Gentlemen,
It is a sore age, very sore age, lewd age,
And women now are like old Knights adventures,
Full of enchanted flames, and dangerous.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent,
sp.l: Where the most danger is, there is most honour.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I grant ye, honour most consists in sufferance,
And by that rule you three should be most honourable.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: A subtle Rogue: but canst thou tell Penurio
Where we might light upon --

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A learned Surgeon?

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: Pox take ye fool; I mean good wholesome wenches.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I'Faith wholesome women will but spoil ye too,
For you are so used to snap-haunces: But take my counsel,
Take fat old women, fat, and five and fifty,
The Dog-days are come in.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Take fat old women?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The fatter and the older, still the better,
You do not know the pleasure of an old Dame,
A fat old Dame, you do not know the knack on it:
They are like our Country groats, as cool as Christmas,
And sure in the keels.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Hang him starved fool, he mocks us.

sp.speaker: 3.Gent.
sp.l: Penurio, thou knowest all the handsome wenches?
What shall I give thee for a Merchants wife now?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I take no money Gentlemen, that is base,
I trade in meat, a Merchants wife will cost ye
A glorious Capon, a great shoulder of Mutton,
And a Tart as big as a Conjurers circle.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: That is cheap enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: And what a Haberdashers?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Worse meat will serve for her: a great Goose Pie,
But you must send it out of the Country to me,
It will not do else: with a peace of Bacon,
And if you can a pot of Butter with it.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Now do I aim at horse-flesh: what a Parsons?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A tithe Pig has no fellow, if I fetch her,
If she be Puritan, Plumb-porridge does it,
And a fat loin of Veal well sauced and roasted.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: We will meet one night, and thou shalt have all these,
On that condition we may have the wenches,
A dainty rascal.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: When your stomachs serve ye,
(For mine is ever ready) I will supply ye.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Farewell, and there is to fill thy paunch.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Brave Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Hold sirra, there.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Any young wench in the Town Sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: It shall go round.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Most honourable Gentlemen,
All these are Courtiers, but they are mere Coxcombs,
And only for a wench, their purses open,
Nor have they so much judgment left to choose her;
If ever they call upon me I will so fit them,
I have a pack of wry-mouthed mackrel Ladies,
Stink like a standing ditch, and those dear Damsels;
But I forgot my business, I thank ye Monsieurs,
I have a thousand whimsies in my brains now.

body.stage: Enter (to a Banket) Duches, Syenna, Lords, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Your Grace shall now perceive how much we honour ye
And in what dear regard we hold your friendship
Will you sit Sir, and grace this homely Banquet?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Madam,to your poor friend you are too magnificent.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: To the Dukes health, and all the joys I wish him,
Let no man miss this cup: have we no Music?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Your noble favours still you heap upon me,
But where is my virtuous Mistress, such a Feast,
And not her sparkling beauty here to bless it?
Methinks it should not be, it shows not fully.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Young Ladies Sir, are long, and curious
In putting on their trims, forget how day goes,
And then it is their good morrow when they are ready:
Go some and call her, and wait upon her hither,
Tell her the Duke and I desire her company:
I warrant ye, a hundred dressings now
She has surveyed, this, and that fashion looked on,
For Ruffs and Gowns; cast this away, these Jewels
Suited to these and these knots: on my life Sir,
She fears your curious eye will soon discover else:
Why stand ye still, why gape ye on one another?
Did I not bid ye go and tell my Daughter?
Are ye nailed here? nor stir? nor speak? who am I,
And who are you?

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: Pardon me, gracious Lady,
The fear to tell you that you would not hear of
Makes us all dumb, the Princess is gone, Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Gone? whither gone? some wiser fellow answer me.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: We sought the Court all over, and believe Lady,
No news of where she is, nor how conveyed hence.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: It cannot be, it must not be.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: It is true Madam,
No room in all the Court but we searched through it,
Her women found her want first, and they cried to us.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Gone? stolen away? I am abused, dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: It is I that am abused,it is I dishonoured,
Is this your welcome, this your favour to me?
To foist a trick upon me, this trick too,
To cheat me of my love? Am I not worthy?
Or since I was your Guest, am I grown odious?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Your Grace mistakes me, as I have a life, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And I another, I will never bear this,
Never endure this door.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: But hear me patiently.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Give me my love.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: As soon as care can find her,
And all care shall be used.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And all my care too,
To be revenged; I smell the trick, it is too rank,
Fie, how it smells of the Mother.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You wrong me, Duke.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: For this disgrace ten thousand Florentines:
Shall pay their dearest bloods, and dying curse ye,
And so I turn away, your mortal enemy.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: Since ye are so high and hot Sir, ye have half armed us,
Be careful of the Town, of all the Castles,
And see supplies of Soldiers everywhere,
And Musters for the Field, when he invites us,
For he shall know it is not high words can fright us.
My Daughter gone? has she so finely cozened me?
This is for Silvio's sake sure, O cunning false one;
Publish a Proclamation thorough the Dukedom.
That whosoever can bring to the Court young Silvio,
Alive or dead, beside our thanks and favour,
Shall have two thousand Ducats for his labour;
See it despatched, and sent in haste: O base one.

body.stage: Enter Isabella, and Penurio with a Light.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Was it thou with Rugio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes marry was I closely.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And does he still remember his poor Mistress?
Does he desire to see me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes, and presently:
Puts off all business else, lives in that memory,
And will be here according to directions.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: But where is thy Master?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Where a coxcomb should be,
Waiting at Court with his Jewels,
Safe for this night I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I am bound to thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would ye were, as close as I could tie ye,

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Thou art my best, my truest friend.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I labour,
I moil and toil for ye: I am your hackney.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: If ever I be able --

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Steal the great Cheese Mistress,
Was sent him out of the Country.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Anything.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That is meat, it is lawful Mistress: where is the Castle Custard
He got at Court?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: He has locked it in his study.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Get a warrant to search for counterfeit gold.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Give me thy Candle,
I will find a time to be thy careful Cater.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And many a time I will find to be his Cook,
And dress his Calves head to the sweetest sauce Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: To bed Penurio, go, the rest is my charge,
I will keep the Watch out.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now if you spare him --

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Peace fool,
I hope my Rugio will not fail, it would vex me:
Now to my string; so, sure he cannot miss now,
And this end to my finger:I will lie down,
For on a sudden I am wondrous heavy,
It is very late too; if he come, and find this,
And pull it, though it be with easy motion
I shall soon waken, and as soon be with him.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Thou secret friend, how am I bound to love thee,
And how to hug thee for thy private service?
Thou art the Star all my suspicions sail by,
The fixed point my wronged honour turns to,
By thee I shall know all, find all the subtleties
Of devilish women, that torment me daily:
Thou art my Conjurer, my Spell, my Spirit,
All is hushed and still, no sound of any stirring,
No tread of living thing: the Light is in still,
And there is my Wife, how prettily the fool lies,
How sweet, and handsomely, and in her clothes too,
Waiting for me upon my life; her fondness
Would not admit her rest till I came to her:
O careful fool, why am I angry with thee?
Why do I think thou hatest thy loving Husband?
I am an Ass, an over-doting Coxcomb,
And this sweet soul the mirror of perfection:
How admirable fair and delicate,
And how it stirs me, I will sing thy sweets a Requiem,
But will not waken thee.
O fair sweet face, O eyes celestial bright,
Twin-stars in Heaven that now adorn the night;
O fruitful lips, where Cherries ever grow,
And Damask cheeks, where all sweet beauties blow;
O thou from head to foot divinely fair,
Cupids most cunning Nets made of that hair,
And as he weaves himself for curious eyes,
O me, O me, I am caught myself, he cries:
Sweet rest about this sweets and golden sleep,
Soft peaceful thoughts your hourly watches keep,
Whilst I in wonder sing this sacrifice,
To beauty sacred, and those Angel-eyes.
Now will I steal a kiss, a dear kiss from her,
And suck the Rosie breath of this bright beauty;
What a Devil is this? tied to her finger too?
A string, a damned string to give intelligence
O my loved key, how truly hast thou served me;
I will follow this: soft, soft,to the door it goes,
And through to the other side; a damned string it is,
I am abused, topped, Cuckolded, fooled, jaded,
Ridden to death, to madness; stay, this helps not:
Stay, stay, and now invention help me,
I will sit down by her, take this from her easily,
And thus upon mine own: Dog, I shall catch ye,
With all your cunning Sir: I shall light on ye,
I felt it pull sure: yes, but wondrous softly,
It is there again, and harder now, have at ye:
Now and thou scapest, the Devils thy ghostly father.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Sure it was my Husbands voice: The string is gone too ,
He has found the trick on it: I am undone, betrayed,
And if he meet my friend he perishes,
What fortune follows me, what spiteful fortune?
Hoa, Jaquenet.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Here Mistress, do you call me?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Didst thou hear no noise?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I hear my Master mad yonder,
And swears, and chafes --

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Darest thou do one thing for me?
One thing concerns mine honour, all is lost else?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Name what you will.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: It can bring but a beating,
Which I will recompense so largely --

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Name it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Sit here, as if thou wert asleep.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: When he comes in, whatever he do unto thee
(The worst will be but beating) speak not a word,
Not one word as thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I will run through it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I will carry away the Candle.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And I the blows Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Have you put your light out? I shall stumble to ye,
You whore, you cunning whore, I shall catch your rogue too ,
Has light legs else: I had so Ferret-clawed him:
O have I found ye? do ye play at dog-sleep still whore?
Do you think that can protect ye? yes, I will kill thee,
But first I will bring thy friends to view thy villainies,
Thy whorish villainies: and first I will beat thee,
Beat thee to pin-dust, thou salt whore, thou varlet,
Scratch out thine eyes; I will spoil your tempting visage;
Are ye so patient? I will put my nails in deeper,
Is it good whoring? whoring ye base rascal?
Is it good tempting men with strings to ride ye?
So, I will fetch your kindred, and your friends, whore,
And such a Justice I will act upon thee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: What is he gone?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The Devil go with him Mistress,
Has harrowed me, ploughed land was never so harrowed:
I had the most ado to save mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Has paid thee,
But I will heal all again with good gold Jaquenet;
Has damned nails.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: They are ten-penny nails I think Mistress:
I will undertake he shall strike them through an inch board.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Go up, and wash thyself: take my Pomatum,
And now let me alone to end the Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Joq.
sp.l: You had best beware.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I shall deal stoutly with him,
Reach me my book, and see the door made fast wench,
And so good night: now to the matter politic.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: You shall see what she is, what a sweet jewel.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Who is there, what mad-man knocks? is this an hour
And in mine husbands absence?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Will ye open?
You know my voice ye whore, I am that husband:
Do you mark her subtlety? but I have paid her,
I have so firked her face: here is the blood Gentlemen,
Ecce signum: I have spoiled her Goatish beauty,
Observe her how she looks now, how she is painted,
O it is the most wickedest whore, and the most treacherous --

body.stage: Enter Lopez, Bartello, Gent. and two Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here walks my Cousin full of meditation,
Armed with religious thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is this the monster?

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: Is this the subject of that rage you talked of,
That naughty woman you had pulled a pieces?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Here is no such thing.

sp.speaker: 1.Gentlew.
sp.l: How have ye wronged this beauty?
Are not you mad my friend? what time of the Moon is it?
Have not you Maggots in your brains?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It is she sure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Where is the scratched face ye spoke of, the torn garments,
And all the hair plucked off her head?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Believe me,
It were better far you had lost your pair of pebbles,
Than she the least adornment of that sweetness.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Is not this blood?

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: This is a monstrous folly,
A base abuse.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Thus he does ever use me,
And sticks me up a wonder, not a woman,
Nothing I do but subject to suspicion;
Nothing I can do able to content him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Lopez, you must not use this.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlew.
sp.l: It were not amiss Sir,
To give ye sauce to your meat, and suddenly.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: You that dare wrong a woman of her goodness,
Thou have a wife, thou have a Bear tied to thee,
To scratch thy jealous itch, were all on my mind,
I mean all women, we would soon disburthen ye
Of that that breeds these fits, these dog-flaws in ye,
A Sow-guelder should trim ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A rare cure Lady,
And one as fit for him as a Thief for a halter,
You see this youth: will you not cry him quittance,
Body me, I would pine, but I would pepper him,
I will come anon, he, hang him, poor pompillion:
How like a wench bepissed he looks, I will come Lady:
Lopez, the Law must teach ye what a wife is,
A good, a virtuous wife.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I will never live with him,
I crave your loves all to make known my cause,
That so a fair Divorce may pass between us,
I am weary of my life: in danger hourly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You see how rude you are, I will not miss ye,
Insufferable rude: I will pay him soundly,
You should be whipped in Bedlam:I will reward him.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlew.
sp.l: Whipping is too good.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I think I am alive still,
And in my wits.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I will put a trick upon him,
And get his goods Confiscate: you shall have them;
I will not fail at nine.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I think I am here too,
And once I would have sworn I had taken her napping,
I think my name is Lopez.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Fie for shame Sir,
You see you have abused her, foully wronged her,
Hung scandalous and course opinions on her,
Which now you find but children of suspicion:
Ask her forgiveness, show a penitence,
She is my Kins-woman, and what she suffers
Under so base and beastly jealousies,
I will redress else, I will seek satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why, every Boy in the Town will piss upon thee.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: Down on your marrow-bones.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Even sorry from my heart: forgive me sweet wife,
Here I confess most freely I have wronged ye,
As freely here I beg a pardon of ye,
From this hour no debate, no cross suspicion --

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: To show ye Sir I understand a wives part,
Thus I assure my love, and seal your pardon.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlew.
sp.l: It is well done, now to bed and there confirm it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And so good night.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Aware relapses, Lopez.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Now Isabella tell me truth, and suddenly,
And do not juggle with me, nor dissemble,
For as I have a life ye die then: I am not mad,
Nor does the Devil work upon my weakness,
Tell me the trick of this, and tell me freely.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Will then that satisfy ye?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: If ye deal ingenuously.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I will tell ye all, and tell ye true and freely,
Bartello was the end of all this jealousy,
His often visitations brought by you, first
Bred all these fits, and these suspicions:
I knew your false key, and accordingly
I framed my plot, to have him take him finely,
Too poor a penance for the wrong his wife bears,
His worthy virtuous wife: I felt it sensibly
When ye took off the string, and was much pleased in it,
Because I wished his importunate dotage paid well,
And had you staid two minutes more, ye had had him.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This sounds like truth.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Because this shall be certain,
Next time he comes, as long he cannot tarry,
Yourself shall see, and hear, his lewd temptations.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Till then I am satisfied, and if this prove true,
Henceforward Mistress of yourself I give ye,
And I to serve ye: For my lusty Captain,
I will make him dance, and make him think the Devil
Claws at his breech, and yet I will not hurt him:
Come now to bed, and prove but constant this way,
I will prove the man you ever wished.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You have blessed me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What labour and what travel have I run Through?
And through what Cities to absolve this Riddle?
Diviners, Dreamers, Schoolmen, deep Magicians,
All have I tried, and all give several meanings,
And from all hope of any future happiness,
To this place am I come at length, the country,
The people simple, plain, and harmless witty,
Whose honest labours Heaven rewards with plenty
Of Corn, Wine, Oil, which they again, as thankful,
To their new Crops, new pastimes celebrate,
And crown their joyful harvests with new voices;
By a rich farmer here I am entertained,
And ranked among the number of his Servants,
Not guessing what I am, but what he would have me,
Here may be so much wit (though much I fear it)
To undo this knotty question; and would to Heaven
My fortunes had been hatched with theirs, as innocent,
And never known a pitch above their plainness.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: That it is, that it is, what is this word now? this
Is a plaguey word, that it is, r.e.a. that it is, reason,
By your leave, Master. Soto, by your leave, you are too quick, Sir,
There is a strange parlous T. before the reason,
A very tall T. which makes the word High Treason.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What Treason is that? does this fellow understand Himself?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Pitch will infect, I will meddle no more with this gear;
What a Devil ails this fellow? this foolish fellow,
Being admitted to be one of us too,
That are the masters of the Sports proceeding,
Thus to appear, before me too, unmorrissed?
Do you know me friend?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You are my Masters Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And do you know what sports are now in season?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I hear there are some afoot .

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Where are your Bells then?
Your Rings, your Ribbons, friend? and your clean Napkins?
Your nosegay in your hat, pinned up, am not I here?
My fathers eldest Son, and at this time, Sir,
I would have ye know it, though ye be ten times his servant,
A better man than my father far, Lord of this Harvest, Sir,
And shall a man of my place want attendance?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It was want of knowledge, Sir, not duty, bred this,
I would have made suit else for your Lordships service.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: In some sort I am satisfied now, mend your manners,
But thou art a melancholy fellow, vengeance melancholy,
And that may breed a insurrection amongst us;
Go to , I will lay the best part of two pots now
Thou art in love, and I can guess with whom too,
I saw the wench that twired and twinkled at thee,
The other day; the wench that is new come hither,
The young smug wench.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You know more than I feele Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Go to , I will be thy friend, I will speak a good word for thee,
And thou shalt have my Lordships countenance to her;
May be I have had a snap myself, may be I, may be no,
We Lords are allowed a little more.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is fit Sir;
I humbly thank ye, you are too too tender of me,
But what Sir, I beseech ye, was that paper,
Your Lordship was so studiously employed in,
When ye came out adoors ?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Thou meanest this paper.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That Sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Why, it is a Proclamation,
A notable piece of villainy, as ever thou heardest in thy life,
By mine honour it is.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How Sir? or what concerns it?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: It comes ye from the Duchess, a plaguey wise woman,
To apprehend the body of one Silvio,
As arrant a Rascal as ever pissed against post,
And this same Silvio, or this foresaid rascal,
To bring before her, live or dead; for which good service
The man that brings him, has two thousand Ducats;
Is not this notable matter now?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is so indeed,
This Proclamation bears my bane about it;
